etymologies: late 16th century (in the sense ‘throw or cast on something’): from Latin inject- ‘thrown in’, from the verb inicere, from in- ‘into’ + jacere ‘throw’

definitions: introduce (a liquid, especially a drug or vaccine) into the body with a syringe

examples.text: the doctor injected a painkilling drug

shortDefinitions: introduce drug etc. into body with syringe

definitions: administer a drug or medicine by syringe to (a person or animal)

examples.text: he was forcibly injected with a sedative

definitions: inject oneself with a narcotic drug, especially habitually

examples.text: people who want to stop injecting

definitions: introduce (something) under pressure into a passage, cavity, or solid material

examples.text: inject the foam and allow it to expand

shortDefinitions: introduce something under pressure into cavity etc.

definitions: introduce or feed (a current, beam of particles, etc.) into a substance or device.
shortDefinitions: introduce current etc. into substance or device

definitions: introduce (a new or different element) into something

examples.text: she tried to inject scorn into her tone

definitions: imbue something with (a new element)

examples.text: he injected his voice with a confidence he didn't feel

definitions: place (a spacecraft or other object) into an orbit or trajectory

examples.text: many meteoroids are injected into hyperbolic orbits

etymologies: Middle English: via Old French from Latin heres

definitions: a person legally entitled to the property or rank of another on that person's death

examples.text: his eldest son and heir
the heir to the throne

shortDefinitions: person legally entitled to property or rank of another on that person's death

definitions: a person who inherits and continues the work of a predecessor

examples.text: they saw themselves as heirs of the Cubists

shortDefinitions: person who inherits and continues work of predecessor

definitions: relating to or denoting a course of study undertaken after completing a first degree

examples.text: a postgraduate degree

shortDefinitions: of course of study undertaken after completing first degree

definitions: a student engaged in a postgraduate course.

etymologies: late 15th century (formerly also as ingrave): from en-, in-‘in, on’ + grave, influenced by obsolete French engraver

definitions: cut or carve (a text or design) on the surface of a hard object

examples.text: my name was engraved on the ring

definitions: cut or carve a text or design on (a hard object)

examples.text: the crystal glasses were engraved with the Queen's cipher

definitions: cut (a design) as lines on a metal plate for printing

examples.text: his drawings of public buildings were engraved by Edward Rooker

definitions: be permanently fixed in (one's memory or mind)

examples.text: the image would be forever engraved in his memory

etymologies: Middle English (as an adjective): via Old French from medieval Latin festivalis, from Latin festivus, from festum, (plural) festa ‘feast’

definitions: a day or period of celebration, typically for religious reasons

examples.text: traditional Jewish festivals

definitions: an organized series of concerts, plays, or films, typically one held annually in the same place

examples.text: a major international festival of song

shortDefinitions: organized series of concerts, plays, or films

etymologies: Middle English: from mis- + hap

definitions: an unlucky accident

examples.text: although there were a few minor mishaps, none of the pancakes stuck to the ceiling
the event passed without mishap

etymologies: mid 17th century: from French caractéristique or medieval Latin characteristicus, from Greek kharaktēristikos, from kharaktēr ‘a stamping tool’

definitions: typical of a particular person, place, or thing

examples.text: he began with a characteristic attack on extremism

shortDefinitions: typical of particular person or thing

definitions: a feature or quality belonging typically to a person, place, or thing and serving to identify them

examples.text: certain defining characteristics of the school emerge from the study

shortDefinitions: feature or quality belonging typically to person

definitions: the whole number or integral part of a logarithm, which gives the order of magnitude of the original number.
shortDefinitions: whole number or integral part of logarithm

etymologies: 1950s: from Latin numerus ‘a number’, on the pattern of literate

definitions: having a good basic knowledge of arithmetic; able to understand and work with numbers

examples.text: teachers should ensure that their pupils are literate and numerate

shortDefinitions: having good basic knowledge of arithmetic

etymologies: Old English hrycg ‘spine, crest’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch rug and German Rücken ‘back’

definitions: a long, narrow hilltop, mountain range, or watershed

examples.text: the North-East ridge of Everest

definitions: the line or edge formed where the two sloping sides of a roof meet at the top

examples.text: the roof was unusual due to the relative heights of the eaves and the ridge

shortDefinitions: line or edge formed where two sloping sides of roof meet at top

definitions: a narrow raised band on a surface

examples.text: buff your nails in order to smooth ridges

definitions: a raised strip of arable land, especially (in medieval fields) one of a set separated by furrows

examples.text: a path led through the ridges and furrows of fields long left to nature

definitions: an elongated region of high barometric pressure

examples.text: a high-pressure ridge helping to steer cyclones further south

shortDefinitions: elongated region of high barometric pressure

definitions: mark with or form into narrow raised bands

examples.text: a field ploughed in narrow stretches that are ridged up slightly
the table's steel surface was ridged with a network of channels

shortDefinitions: mark with or form into ridges

definitions: (of a surface) form into or rise up as a ridge

examples.text: the crust of the earth ridged

shortDefinitions: form into or rise up as ridge

etymologies: Old English therscold, threscold; related to German dialect Drischaufel; the first element is related to thresh (in a Germanic sense ‘tread’), but the origin of the second element is unknown

definitions: a strip of wood or stone forming the bottom of a doorway and crossed in entering a house or room

examples.text: he stood on the threshold of Sheila's bedroom

shortDefinitions: strip of wood or stone forming bottom of doorway

definitions: a point of entry or beginning

examples.text: she was on the threshold of a dazzling career

definitions: the beginning of an airport runway on which an aircraft is attempting to land.
shortDefinitions: beginning of airport runway on which aircraft is attempting to land

definitions: the magnitude or intensity that must be exceeded for a certain reaction, phenomenon, result, or condition to occur or be manifested

examples.text: nothing happens until the signal passes the threshold
a threshold level

shortDefinitions: magnitude or intensity that must be exceeded for certain reaction

definitions: the maximum level of radiation or a concentration of a substance considered to be acceptable or safe

examples.text: their water would meet the safety threshold of 50 milligrams of nitrates per litre

shortDefinitions: maximum level of radiation or concentration of substance considered to be acceptable or safe

definitions: the level at which one starts to feel or react to something

examples.text: he has a low boredom threshold

shortDefinitions: level at which one starts to feel or react to something

definitions: a level, rate, or amount at which something comes into effect

examples.text: the inheritance tax threshold

shortDefinitions: level, rate, or amount at which something comes into effect

etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘advantage, benefit’): from Old French, from Latin profectus ‘progress, profit’, from proficere ‘to advance’, from pro- ‘on behalf of’ + facere ‘do’. The verb is from Old French profiter

definitions: a financial gain, especially the difference between the amount earned and the amount spent in buying, operating, or producing something

examples.text: record pre-tax profits
his eyes brightened at the prospect of profit

definitions: advantage; benefit

examples.text: there's no profit in screaming at referees from the bench

definitions: obtain a financial advantage or benefit

examples.text: the only people to profit from the episode were the lawyers

definitions: obtain an advantage or benefit

examples.text: not all children would profit from this kind of schooling

definitions: be beneficial to

examples.text: it would profit us to change our plans

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French premisse, from medieval Latin praemissa (propositio) ‘(proposition) set in front’, from Latin praemittere, from prae ‘before’ + mittere ‘send’

definitions: a previous statement or proposition from which another is inferred or follows as a conclusion

examples.text: if the premise is true, then the conclusion must be true

shortDefinitions: previous statement from which another is inferred

definitions: an assertion or proposition which forms the basis for a work or theory

examples.text: the fundamental premise of the report

shortDefinitions: proposition forming basis for theory etc.

definitions: base an argument, theory, or undertaking on

examples.text: the reforms were premised on our findings

definitions: state or presuppose (something) as a premise

examples.text: one school of thought premised that the cosmos is indestructible

definitions: state by way of introduction

examples.text: I will premise generally that I hate lecturing

etymologies: Old English sēam, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zoom and German Saum

definitions: a line where two pieces of fabric are sewn together in a garment or other article.
shortDefinitions: line where two pieces of fabric are sewn together in garment

definitions: a line where the edges of two pieces of wood, wallpaper, or another material touch each other

examples.text: the task involved clamping the panels into position and arc welding a seam to join them

shortDefinitions: line where edges of two pieces of wood, wallpaper, or another material touch each other

definitions: a long thin indentation or scar

examples.text: the track cleaves a seam through corn

definitions: an underground layer of a mineral such as coal or gold

examples.text: the buried forests became seams of coal

definitions: a supply of something valuable

examples.text: Sunderland have a rich seam of experienced players

definitions: a trace or presence of something

examples.text: there is a seam of despondency in Stipe's words

definitions: sew the seam of or join with a seam

examples.text: our stockings are seamed by hand
seam the fabric widths together

definitions: make a long, narrow indentation in

examples.text: deep wrinkles seamed his face

etymologies: mid 16th century (as a noun): via Latin from Greek paraphrasis, from paraphrazein, from para- (expressing modification) + phrazein ‘tell’

definitions: express the meaning of (something written or spoken) using different words, especially to achieve greater clarity

examples.text: you can either quote or paraphrase literary texts

shortDefinitions: express meaning of something using different words

definitions: a rewording of something written or spoken

examples.text: scattered here and there in the text are frank paraphrases of lines from Virgil, Cicero, and Quintilian
it is characteristic of poetic metaphors that they are not susceptible to paraphrase

shortDefinitions: rewording of something written or spoken

definitions: estimate (something) to be smaller or less important than it really is

examples.text: they have grossly underestimated the extent of the problem

shortDefinitions: estimate something to be smaller or less important than it really is

definitions: regard (someone) as less capable than they really are

examples.text: he had underestimated the new President

shortDefinitions: regard someone as less capable than they really are

definitions: an estimate that is too low

examples.text: £7.5 million is a considerable underestimate

etymologies: late 19th century: from French, from auto- ‘self’ + mobile ‘mobile’

definitions: a car

examples.text: computer chips are now a critical component in automobiles and other manufactured goods
the automobile industry

etymologies: Middle English: shortening of Old French esquare (noun), esquarre (past participle, used as an adjective), esquarrer (verb), based on Latin quadra ‘square’

definitions: a plane figure with four equal straight sides and four right angles

examples.text: a grid of ruled squares

shortDefinitions: plane figure with four equal straight sides and four right angles

definitions: a thing that is square or approximately square in shape

examples.text: she tore a bit of cloth into a four-inch square

shortDefinitions: thing that is square or square in shape

definitions: a thing having the shape or approximate shape of a cube

examples.text: a small square of chocolate

shortDefinitions: thing having shape or approximate shape of cube

definitions: a small square area on the board used in a game

examples.text: move the white king's pawn forward two squares

shortDefinitions: small square area on board used in game

definitions: a body of infantry drawn up in rectangular form.
shortDefinitions: body of infantry drawn up in rectangular form

definitions: a unit of 100 square ft used as a measure of flooring, roofing, etc.
shortDefinitions: unit of 100 square ft used as measure of flooring

definitions: a square scarf.
a mortar board.
the portion of the cover of a bound book which projects beyond the pages.
shortDefinitions: portion of cover of bound book which projects beyond pages

definitions: an open, typically four-sided, area surrounded by buildings in a village, town, or city

examples.text: a market square
Leicester Square

definitions: an open area at the meeting of streets.
shortDefinitions: open area at meeting of streets

definitions: a closer-cut area at the centre of a ground, any strip of which may be prepared as a wicket.
shortDefinitions: closer-cut area at centre of ground

definitions: an area within a military barracks or camp used for drill.
shortDefinitions: area within military barracks or camp used for drill

definitions: a block of buildings bounded by four streets.
shortDefinitions: block of buildings bounded by four streets

definitions: the product of a number multiplied by itself

examples.text: a circle's area is proportional to the square of its radius

shortDefinitions: product of number multiplied by itself

definitions: an L-shaped or T-shaped instrument used for obtaining or testing right angles

examples.text: a carpenter's square

shortDefinitions: L-shaped or T-shaped instrument used for obtaining or testing right angles

definitions: an aspect of 90° (one quarter of a circle)

examples.text: Venus in square to Jupiter

definitions: a person considered to be old-fashioned or boringly conventional in attitude or behaviour

examples.text: Reg is such a square

shortDefinitions: person considered to be old-fashioned or boringly conventional

definitions: a cigarette containing tobacco rather than cannabis.
shortDefinitions: cigarette containing tobacco rather than cannabis

definitions: a square meal

examples.text: three squares a day

definitions: having the shape or approximate shape of a square

examples.text: a square table

shortDefinitions: having shape or approximate shape of square

definitions: having the shape or approximate shape of a cube

examples.text: a square block of flats

shortDefinitions: having shape or approximate shape of cube

definitions: having or in the form of two right angles

examples.text: a suitable length of wood with square ends

shortDefinitions: having or in form of two right angles

definitions: having an outline resembling two corners of a square

examples.text: his square jaw

shortDefinitions: having outline resembling two corners of square

definitions: broad and solid in shape

examples.text: he was short and square

definitions: denoting a unit of measurement equal to the area of a square whose side is of the unit specified

examples.text: 30,000 square feet of new gallery space

shortDefinitions: denoting unit of measurement equal to area of square whose side is of unit specified

definitions: denoting the length of each side of a square shape or object

examples.text: the office was fifteen feet square

shortDefinitions: denoting length of each side of square shape or object

definitions: at right angles; perpendicular

examples.text: these lines must be square to the top and bottom marked edges

definitions: in a direction transversely across the field or pitch

examples.text: Keen's square pass was rammed home first time by Bishop

shortDefinitions: in direction transversely across field or pitch

definitions: having or denoting an aspect of 90°

examples.text: Jupiter is square to the Sun

definitions: level or parallel

examples.text: place two pieces of wood one on top of the other, ensuring that they are exactly square

definitions: properly arranged; in good order

examples.text: we should get everything square before we leave

definitions: compatible or in agreement

examples.text: he wanted to make sure we were square with the court's decision and not subject to a lawsuit

definitions: fair and honest

examples.text: she'd been as square with him as anybody could be

definitions: (of two people) owing nothing to each other

examples.text: an acknowledgement that we are square

definitions: with both players or sides having equal scores in a game

examples.text: the goal brought the match all square once again

shortDefinitions: with both players or sides having equal scores in game

definitions: old-fashioned or boringly conventional

examples.text: Elvis was anything but square

definitions: (of rhythm) simple and straightforward.
directly; straight

examples.text: the ball hit me square in the forehead

definitions: fairly; honestly

examples.text: I'd acted square with him

definitions: in a direction transversely across the field or pitch

examples.text: the ball bounced almost square to the left

shortDefinitions: in direction transversely across field or pitch

definitions: make square or rectangular; give a square or rectangular cross section to

examples.text: you can square off the other edge
they felled and squared the timber themselves

definitions: mark out in squares

examples.text: that this watercolour was a first draft is made clear by the fact that the sheet of paper has been squared

definitions: multiply (a number) by itself

examples.text: 5 squared equals 25

definitions: balance (an account)

examples.text: institutions are anxious to square their books before the election

definitions: make the score of (a match or game) even

examples.text: his goal squared the match 1–1

shortDefinitions: make score of match or game even

definitions: bring (one's shoulders) into a position in which they appear square and broad, typically to prepare oneself for a difficult task or event

examples.text: chin up, shoulders squared, she stepped into the room

shortDefinitions: bring one's shoulders into position in which they appear square and broad

definitions: adopt a posture of defence.
secure the help or acquiescence of (someone), especially by offering an inducement

examples.text: faced with such declarations, politicians were resolved to squash or square the press

definitions: pass (a ball) across the field, especially towards the centre.
set (a yard or other part of a ship) at right angles to the keel or other point of reference.
shortDefinitions: set yard part of ship at right angles to keel

definitions: (of a planet) have a square aspect with (another planet or position)

examples.text: Saturn squares the Sun on the 17th

etymologies: late 16th century: from medieval Latin manuscriptus, from manu ‘by hand’ + scriptus ‘written’ (past participle of scribere)

definitions: a book, document, or piece of music written by hand rather than typed or printed

examples.text: an illuminated manuscript
early Gothic manuscripts

shortDefinitions: book, document, or piece of music written by hand rather than typed or printed

definitions: an author's handwritten or typed text that has not yet been published

examples.text: several manuscripts in his own hand
her autobiography remained in manuscript

shortDefinitions: author's handwritten or typed text that has not yet been published

etymologies: late 15th century (in gravity (sense 2)): from Old French, or from Latin gravitas ‘weight, seriousness’, from gravis ‘heavy’. gravity (sense 1) dates from the 17th century

definitions: the force that attracts a body towards the centre of the earth, or towards any other physical body having mass.
the degree of intensity of gravity, measured by acceleration.
extreme importance; seriousness

examples.text: crimes of the utmost gravity

definitions: solemnity of manner

examples.text: has the poet ever spoken with greater eloquence or gravity?

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French condicion (noun), condicionner (verb), from Latin condicio(n-) ‘agreement’, from condicere ‘agree upon’, from con- ‘with’ + dicere ‘say’

definitions: the state of something with regard to its appearance, quality, or working order

examples.text: the wiring is in good condition
the bridge is in an extremely dangerous condition

definitions: a person's or animal's state of health or physical fitness

examples.text: the baby was in good condition at birth
she was in a serious condition

definitions: an illness or other medical problem

examples.text: a heart condition

definitions: the situation in life of a particular group

examples.text: the sorrows of the human condition

definitions: social position

examples.text: those of humbler condition

definitions: the circumstances or factors affecting the way in which people live or work, especially with regard to their well-being

examples.text: harsh working conditions

definitions: the factors or prevailing situation influencing the performance or outcome of a process

examples.text: present market conditions

definitions: the prevailing state of the weather, ground, or sea at a particular time, especially as it affects a sporting event

examples.text: the appalling conditions determined the style of play

definitions: a situation that must exist before something else is possible or permitted

examples.text: for a member to borrow money, three conditions have to be met
all personnel should comply with this policy as a condition of employment

phrases.text: in no condition to do something

definitions: have a significant influence on or determine (the manner or outcome of something)

examples.text: national choices are conditioned by the international political economy

definitions: train or accustom to behave in a certain way or to accept certain circumstances

examples.text: our minds are heavily conditioned and circumscribed by habit
they are beliefs which he has been conditioned to accept

shortDefinitions: train to behave in certain way

definitions: bring (something) into the desired state for use

examples.text: a product for conditioning leather

shortDefinitions: bring into desired state for use

definitions: make (a person or animal) fit and healthy

examples.text: O'Brien conditioned winners of 13 European Derbies during his career
he was six feet two of perfectly conditioned muscle and bone

definitions: bring (beer) to maturation after fermentation while the yeast is still present

examples.text: beer conditioned in the bottle or cask still contains live, active yeast and should be drunk as soon as possible

shortDefinitions: bring beer or stout to maturation

definitions: (of a beer) become conditioned

examples.text: brews that are allowed to condition in the bottle

definitions: apply a conditioner to (the hair)

examples.text: I condition my hair regularly

shortDefinitions: apply substance to skin or hair

definitions: set prior requirements on (something) before it can occur or be done

examples.text: an insurance company is free to limit and condition its liability as it sees fit

phrases.text: in no condition to do something

etymologies: early 17th century: from French spécialiser, from spécial ‘special’

definitions: concentrate on and become expert in a particular subject or skill

examples.text: he could specialize in tropical medicine

shortDefinitions: concentrate on and become expert in particular subject or skill

definitions: confine oneself to providing a particular product or service

examples.text: the firm specialized in commercial brochures

shortDefinitions: confine oneself to providing particular product or service

definitions: make a habit of engaging in a particular activity

examples.text: a group of writers have specialized in attacking the society they live in

shortDefinitions: make habit of engaging in particular activity

definitions: adapt or set apart (an organ or part) to serve a special function or to suit a particular way of life

examples.text: zooids specialized for different functions

shortDefinitions: adapt or set apart organ or part to serve special function or to suit particular way of life

etymologies: Middle English: from under- + the verb mine, probably suggested by Middle Dutch ondermineren

definitions: erode the base or foundation of (a rock formation)

examples.text: the flow of water had undermined pillars supporting the roof

definitions: dig or excavate beneath (a building or fortification) so as to make it collapse

examples.text: the demolition engineers did eventually undermine two of the tower's six sides

shortDefinitions: dig or excavate beneath building or fortification so as to make it collapse

definitions: lessen the effectiveness, power, or ability of, especially gradually or insidiously

examples.text: this could undermine years of hard work

etymologies: mid 19th century: from French

definitions: a decorative image or design, especially a repeated one forming a pattern

examples.text: the colourful hand-painted motifs which adorn narrowboats

definitions: a decorative device applied to a garment or textile

examples.text: floral or other motifs are then appliquéd to net veils

definitions: a dominant or recurring idea in an artistic work

examples.text: superstition is a recurring motif in the book

shortDefinitions: dominant or recurring idea in artistic work

definitions: a leitmotif or figure.

examples.text: in this opera, Verdi used identifying motifs

definitions: a distinctive sequence on a protein or DNA, having a three-dimensional structure that allows binding interactions to occur.
shortDefinitions: distinctive sequence on protein or DNA

etymologies: early 17th century: from Latin fatuus ‘foolish’ + -ous

definitions: silly and pointless

examples.text: a fatuous comment

definitions: sign and accept liability under (an insurance policy), thus guaranteeing payment in case loss or damage occurs

examples.text: the policy, underwritten at Lloyd's, indemnifies trustees against loss arising from wrongful acts
the individuals whose assets support underwriting at Lloyd's

shortDefinitions: sign and accept liability under insurance policy, thus guaranteeing payment in case loss or damage occurs

definitions: accept (a liability or risk) under the terms of an insurance policy

examples.text: the insurance companies have underwritten just over half the risk

shortDefinitions: accept liability or risk in this way

definitions: (of a bank or other financial institution) pledge to buy all the unsold shares in (an issue of new shares)

examples.text: the purchase is being paid for by a share issue, which has been underwritten

shortDefinitions: (of bank or other financial institution) pledge to buy all unsold shares in

definitions: undertake to finance or otherwise support or guarantee (something)

examples.text: they were willing to underwrite, in part, the construction of a ship

shortDefinitions: undertake to finance or otherwise support or guarantee

definitions: write (something) below something else, especially other written matter

examples.text: each subscriber should underwrite his reason for the place he allots his candidate

etymologies: Middle English deierie, from deie ‘dairymaid’ (in Old English dǣge ‘female servant’), of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse deigja, also to dough and to the second element of Old English hlǣfdige (see lady)

definitions: a building or room for the processing, storage, and distribution of milk and milk products.
shortDefinitions: place for processing and storing milk

definitions: a shop where milk and milk products are sold.
shortDefinitions: shop selling milk and milk products

definitions: milk and milk products collectively

examples.text: I rely on soya as a substitute for dairy

definitions: a small grocery shop.
containing or made from milk

examples.text: local dairy foods

definitions: concerned with the production of milk

examples.text: a dairy farmer

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French conquest(e), based on Latin conquirere (see conquer)

definitions: the subjugation and assumption of control of a place or people by military force

examples.text: the conquest of the Aztecs by the Spanish

definitions: a territory which has been subjugated by military force

examples.text: colonial conquests

definitions: the invasion and assumption of control of England by William of Normandy in 1066.
shortDefinitions: Norman assumption of control in England

definitions: the overcoming of a problem or weakness

examples.text: the conquest of inflation

definitions: the successful ascent of a mountain, especially one not previously climbed

examples.text: the conquest of Everest

definitions: a person whose affection or favour has been won

examples.text: she was someone he could display before his friends as his latest conquest

shortDefinitions: person whose affection has been won

etymologies: Middle English (originally northern): related to Old Norse drukkna ‘to be drowned’, also to drink

definitions: die through submersion in and inhalation of water

examples.text: a motorist drowned when her car plunged off the edge of a quay
two fishermen were drowned when their motorboat capsized

definitions: deliberately kill (a person or animal) by drowning

examples.text: he immediately drowned four of the dogs
they committed suicide by jumping into the sea and drowning themselves

definitions: submerge or flood (an area)

examples.text: when the ice melted the valleys were drowned

definitions: (of a sound) make (another sound) inaudible by being much louder

examples.text: his voice was drowned out by the approaching engine noise

definitions: be overwhelmed by a large amount of something

examples.text: both business and household sectors are drowning in debt
art dealers are still drowning in a sea of paperwork

shortDefinitions: be overwhelmed by large amount of something

definitions: cover or immerse food in

examples.text: good pizza is not eight inches thick and drowned in tomato sauce

etymologies: early 19th century: from French pseudonyme, from Greek pseudōnymos, from pseudēs ‘false’ + onuma ‘name’

definitions: a fictitious name, especially one used by an author

examples.text: I wrote under the pseudonym of Evelyn Hervey
